author: pauld.9606
content: I was thinking more about interactions between accumulators and epoch-based state eviction.

author: pauld.9606
content: Many witnesses for old epochs will be proofs-of-exclusion.

author: pauld.9606
content: There is an engineering solution to do many proofs-of-exclusion without a witness.

author: pauld.9606
content: A bloom filter returns either "possibly in set" or "definitely not in set". For "possibly in set", we fall back to our static accumulator for that epoch.

author: pauld.9606
content: Bloom filters can be tuned so that their error rate is low. (I know, an engineering solution.)

author: pauld.9606
content: To prevent attacks on bloom filters, we can key the bloom hashes based on the final root hash for that epoch.

author: pauld.9606
content: The bloom filter calculation is a big step (which is bad for blockchain). But this big step has many months to be computed -- it is calculated when the state is still active, but frozen, i.e. the epoch before the current epoch, before it is evicted. Clients will probably just hard-code them anyway.
